title-group.article-title: Sample Size and Data Monitoring for Clinical Trials With Extremely Low Incidence Rates

abstract.p: In clinical trials, statistical analyses on incidence rates detect significant differences between the responses from groups. Sample size estimation is always one of the key aspects in clinical trials that have limited budgets. A prestudy power analysis for sample size calculation is often performed to select an appropriate sample size that will achieve a desired power (ie, the probability of correctly detecting the significant difference if such a difference truly exists) at a prespecified level of significance. In practice, it is expected that a greater sample size is needed to detect a smaller difference. A much larger sample size is required to detect a relatively small difference, especially for those clinical studies with extremely low incidence rates. Thus, sample size calculation based on prestudy power analysis may not be feasible in practice. In this case, as an alternative, the authors propose to justify a selected sample size based on a precision analysis and a sensitivity analysis. A recommended step-by-step procedure for sample size determination in clinical trials with extremely low incidence rate is given. A statistical procedure for data safety monitoring based on the probability statement during the conduct of the clinical trial is also proposed.

body.p: One of the important challenges in conducting clinical trials to investigate drugs for the treatment of rare diseases is the appropriate use of endpoints.1 Incidence rates of certain events such as adverse events, immune responses, and infections are commonly considered clinical study endpoints for evaluation of safety and efficacy of the test treatment under investigation.2 In clinical trials or epidemiological studies, incidence rate expresses the number of new cases of disease that occur in a defined population of disease-free individuals. The observed incidence rate provides a direct estimate of the probability or risk of illness. Boyle and Parkin3 introduced the methods required for using incidence rates in comparative studies. For example, one may compare incidence rates from different time periods or from different geographical areas in epidemiological studies. In contrast, one may compare incidence rates (eg, adverse events, postsurgery infections, or immune responses for immunogenicity) in clinical trials.4,5 In practice, however, there is little or no discussion available in the literature regarding sample size required to achieve certain statistical inferences (eg, in terms of power or precision) for studies with extremely low incidence rates.

For sample size calculation in clinical trials, a prestudy power analysis is usually performed to determine an appropriate sample size for achieving a desired power (eg, 80% or 90%) to detect a significant difference at a prespecified level of significance (eg, 5%).5,6 The power of a statistical test is the probability of correctly detecting a significant difference if such a difference truly exists. In practice, it is expected that a greater sample size will be needed to detect a smaller difference. A much larger sample size is required for detecting a relatively small difference between groups, especially for clinical trials with extremely low incidence rates. For example, the incidence rate for hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) in studies of diabetes and the immune responses for immunogenicity in studies of biosimilars are usually extremely low. In these cases, sample size calculation based on a prestudy power analysis for detecting a significant difference may not be feasible. Alternatively, as indicated by Chow et al,6 sample size may be justified based on so-called precision analysis for achieving certain statistical assurance (inference).

The objective of this paper is not only to provide a scientific and statistical justification for a selected sample size for clinical studies with extremely low incidence rate based on the precision analysis but also to recommend a step-by-step procedure for choosing an appropriate sample size based on the precision analysis. In addition, a statistical data safety monitoring procedure is developed during the conduct of the study. We start by discussing statistical methods for sample size calculation and justification, including power analysis and precision analysis, and then describe the application of a Bayesian approach with a noninformative uniform prior. Sensitivity analysis for the proposed method is then studied, and an example concerning a clinical trial for evaluating postsurgery infection rate is presented. Finally, we propose a statistical procedure for data safety monitoring based on a probability statement during the conduct of a clinical trial with an extremely low incidence rate. We conclude with brief remarks.

sec.title: Sample Size Determination
sec.p: In clinical trials, a prestudy power analysis for sample size calculation is often performed to ensure that an intended clinical trial will achieve a desired power for correctly detecting a treatment effect at a prespecified level of significance. For clinical trials with extremely low incidence rates, sample size calculation based on power analysis may not be feasible. Alternatively, it is suggested that sample size calculation be done based on precision analysis. In this section, prestudy power analysis and precision analysis for sample size calculation are briefly described.

sec.title: Proposed Procedure for Choosing Sample Size
sec.p: As indicated earlier, for clinical trials with extremely low incidence rates, the sample size required for achieving a desired power to detect a small difference may not be feasible. Sample size justification based on a small difference (absolute change) may not be of practical interest. Alternatively, sample size justification based on relative change is often considered. For example, suppose the postsurgery infection rate for the control group is 2% and the incidence rate for the test group is 1%. Then, the absolute change in infection rate is 1% = 2% – 1%. This small difference may not be of any clinical or practical meaning. However, if we consider relative change, then the difference becomes appealing. In other words, there is 50% relative reduction in infection rate from 2% to 1%. In this section, we propose a procedure based on precision analysis for selecting an appropriate sample size for clinical trials with extremely low incidence rates.
Suppose pR and pT are infection rates for the reference group and the test group, respectively. Define relative improvement (or percentage of improvement) as follows:% improvement=pR−pTpR×100%.

Note that when pR<pT, the above measurement becomes a measure of percentage of worsening. If we consider the precision analysis and the relative improvement at the same time, the following step-by-step procedure for choosing an appropriate sample size is recommended:
Step 1: Determine the maximum error margin allowed. Choose a maximum error margin that you feel comfortable with. In other words, we are 95% confident that the true difference in incidence rate between the two groups is within the maximum error margin.
Step 2: Select the highest percentage of improvement. Since it is expected that the relative improvement in infection rate is somewhere within the range, we may choose the combination of incidence rates that gives the highest percentage of improvement.
Step 3: Select a sample size that reaches statistical significance (ie, those confidence intervals that do not cover 0). In other words, the observed difference found above is not by chance, and it is reproducible if we repeat the study under similar experimental conditions.

Note that with the selected sample size (based on the above procedure), we can also evaluate the corresponding power. If you feel uncomfortable, you can increase the sample size. In practice, the selected sample size should have at least 50% power at a prespecified level of significance.

sec.title: An Example
sec.p:
A medical device company is interested in conducting a clinical trial to evaluate one of its devices for preventing infection post surgery. The infection rate for the reference group is extremely low, ranging from 1.7% to 2.1% with a mean rate of 1.9%. The sponsor expects the infection rate for the test product to be about 1.0% and targets at least 50% improvement in the infection rate post surgery. Based on prestudy power analysis for sample size calculation, a total sample size of 6532 (3266 per group) is required to achieve a 90% power for detecting a difference in infection rate of 0.95% if such a difference truly exists at the 5% level of significance, assuming that the true infection rate for the control group is 1.9%. With this huge sample size, not only can the sponsor not afford to support the study, it may not be of any practical use. Alternatively, we may use the following steps to choose an appropriate sample size for the proposed clinical study as described in previous sections:
Step 1: Assuming that the true infection rate for the control group is 1.95%, we expect that there is a 50% relative reduction for the test group. In other words, the true infection rate for the test group is 0.95%. Now suppose the sponsor is willing to tolerate a 0.5% error margin. Thus, we choose a maximum error margin of 0.05%.
Step 2: We use Table 2 to select the combination of (pR,pT) with the highest possible percentage of improvement. Table 2 suggests that the second column with 53% relative improvement be considered.
Step 3: We then select a sample size that reaches statistical significance. As can be seen from Table 2, n=1100 per group will reach statistical significance (ie, the observed difference is not by chance alone and it is reproducible).

sec.title: Data Safety Monitoring Procedure
sec.p: For clinical trials with extremely low incidence rates, a large sample will be required to observe a few responses. The time and cost are great concerns to the sponsor of the trial. It is then of particular interest to stop the trial early if it appears that the test treatment will not achieve the study objectives. In this section, a statistical data safety monitoring procedure based on probability statement is developed to assist the sponsor in deciding whether the trial should be stopped at interim.

sec.title: Concluding Remarks
sec.p: For clinical trials with extremely low incidence rates, the sample size required for achieving a desired power in order to correctly detect a small difference, if such a difference truly exists, is often very large. A huge sample size may not be practical. This article has proposed an alternative approach based on a precision analysis in conjunction with a sensitivity analysis. The proposed method reduces the sample size required to achieve a desired precision with certain statistical assurance. For this reason, a step-by-step procedure for choosing an appropriate sample size was recommended. The proposed procedure for choosing an appropriate sample size takes the relative improvement into consideration.

For clinical trials with extremely low incidence rates, a large sample will be needed in order to observe a few responses. To the sponsor of the trial, the time required and the costs incurred are of great concern. It is thus of particular interest to stop the trial early if it appears that the test treatment will not achieve the study objectives. Along this line, a statistical data safety monitoring procedure (see Figure 1) based on the probability statement is developed to assist the sponsor in deciding whether the trial should stop at interim. If the observed incidences are within the confidence limit with 95% confidence, then the investigators can check the probabilities for all possible combinations; otherwise, the sponsor can stop the trial.
